page.title: 08Maes-y-groes Farm,Cilcain(2)
page.content: Beef Cattle: Cattle are no longer bred on the farm; instead bull-calves are bought in and raised and fattened before being sold for beef. Usually about forty Friesian calves are purchased each year at the local Mold cattle market. The calves, one week old, may weigh about 50kg. They are fed on reconstituted milk powder for six weeks, with hay and barley-meal being introduced after the first week. The calves are normally bought in the late autumn and are kept inside over the winter, before being let out to graze in June. All the older cattle are kept inside for the winter, often from late November to early May, and are then fed on hay or silage and barley-meal. The barley straw is used for bedding. The fattened bullocks are sold at two years old, when they may weigh 600kg.
